bugs.title: CVE-2018-5703 kernel: net/ipv6/tcp_ipv6.c:tcp_v6_syn_recv_sock function allows attackers to cause a denial of service

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-5703 kernel: net/ipv6/tcp_ipv6.c:tcp_v6_syn_recv_sock function allows attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
The tcp_v6_syn_recv_sock function in net/ipv6/tcp_ipv6.c in the Linux kernel through 4.14.11 allows attackers to cause a denial of service (slab out-of-bounds write) or possibly have unspecified other impact via vectors involving in-kernel TLS implementation. Due to the nature of the flaw, privilege escalation cannot be fully ruled out, although we believe it is unlikely.

References:

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/syzkaller-bugs/0PBeVnSzfqQ/5eXAlM46BQAJ

https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/801530/

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1535111]

Statement:

This issue does not affect the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5, 6, and 7, its real-time kernel, Red Hat Enterprise MRG 2, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 for ARM 64 and Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 for Power 9 LE. The code of in-kernel TLS implementation with the flaw is not enabled and is not built in the products listed.

Due to the nature of the flaw, privilege escalation cannot be fully ruled out, although we believe it is unlikely.

We apologize for the inconvenience.  There is a large number of bugs to go through and several of them have gone stale.  As kernel maintainers, we try to keep up with bugzilla but due the rate at which the upstream kernel project moves, bugs may be fixed without any indication to us. Due to this, we are doing a mass bug update across all of the Fedora 27 kernel bugs.
 
Fedora 27 has now been rebased to 4.15.3-300.f27.  Please test this kernel update (or newer) and let us know if you issue has been resolved or if it is still present with the newer kernel.
 
If you experience different issues, please open a new bug report for those.
This is still open while a proper solution makes its way upstream.

bugs.title: CVE-2018-1065 kernel: netfilter: xtables NULL pointer dereference in ip6_tables.c:ip6t_do_table() leading to a crash

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-1065 kernel: netfilter: xtables NULL pointer dereference in ip6_tables.c:ip6t_do_table() leading to a crash

long_desc.thetext:
The Linux kernel at version 4.15.0-rc9 is vulnerable to a NULL pointer dereference ip6_tables.c:ip6t_do_table() leading to a crash. This vulnerability is only present under certain malformed iptables rulesets.

Inserting malformed rules its a privileged operation as root or a user with CAP_NET_RAW,CAP_NET_ADMIN capabilities ( see man setcap(8) ).

As this requires advanced privileges Red Hat Product Security has rated this flaw as moderate.

Additional References:

Netdev list:
http://lists.openwall.net/netdev/2018/01/27/46

A suggested upstream patch:
http://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/870355/

An upstream patch:
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=57ebd808a97d7

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1547831]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2018:2948 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:2948

bugs.title: System  freezes after OOPS during booting

bugzilla.short_desc: System  freezes after OOPS during booting

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1401069
Screen shot taken with a cell phone showing the last displayed screen with the error.

System freezes after displaying "Oops: 0000 [#1] SMP NOPTI" and call trace when trying to boot an AMD Optiron system running the 4.15.3 or 4.15.4 kernels.  This system booted with no problems using pre-4.15 kernels.
Can you test with the kernel from https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=1050339  ? There is a possible fix there.

Created attachment 1401532
Screen shop taken with cell phone showing 4.15.6 Oops error.

Downloaded and rebooted suggested 4.15.6 kernel.
No Joy.  New screen shot attached.
There was a fix missing from the 4.15 stable branch. I picked it up into 4.15.7, this bug will get updated when it's available.
https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25421751 the IPMI maintainer gave a few more fixes, can you test this scratch build when it finishes?

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #5)
> https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25421751 the IPMI
> maintainer gave a few more fixes, can you test this scratch build when it
> finishes?

Will do, IF it finishes.  https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25421752 still shows at this time that the x86_64 kernel did fail.
Sorry, there was a patch with a missing dependency in the tree, try https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25506144
*** Bug 1551285 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #7)
> Sorry, there was a patch with a missing dependency in the tree, try
> https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=25506144

Installed the task build kernel-4.15.7-301.fc27 for x86_64 and it booted with no errors.  Initial functional testing on the system indicates everything is okay.
Thanks for confirming! Are you okay if I give your name and e-mail to the maintainer to add a Tested-by tag?

(In reply to Laura Abbott from comment #10)
> Thanks for confirming! Are you okay if I give your name and e-mail to the
> maintainer to add a Tested-by tag?

yes, that is fine with me.  Do I close this ticket or do you?
I pushed the patch to the tree. It will get picked up with the next build that happens and the bug will get updated and closed through that process.

bugs.title: CVE-2018-5803 kernel: Missing length check of payload in net/sctp/sm_make_chunk.c:_sctp_make_chunk() function allows denial of service

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-5803 kernel: Missing length check of payload in net/sctp/sm_make_chunk.c:_sctp_make_chunk() function allows denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
An error in the "_sctp_make_chunk()" function (net/sctp/sm_make_chunk.c) when handling SCTP packets length can be exploited by a malicious local user to cause a kernel crash and a DoS.

References:

https://packetstormsecurity.com/files/146620/secunia-sctpmakechunkdos.txt

https://marc.info/?t=151818093200004&r=1&w=2

https://marc.info/?t=151818682600001&r=1&w=2

An upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=07f2c7ab6f8d0a7e7c5764c4e6cc9c52951b9d9c

bugs.title: CVE-2018-7757 kernel: Memory leak in the sas_smp_get_phy_events function in drivers/scsi/libsas/sas_expander.c

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-7757 kernel: Memory leak in the sas_smp_get_phy_events function in drivers/scsi/libsas/sas_expander.c

long_desc.thetext:
Memory leak in the sas_smp_get_phy_events function in drivers/scsi/libsas/sas_expander.c in the Linux kernel allows local users to cause a denial of service (kernel memory exhaustion) via multiple read accesses to files in the /sys/class/sas_phy directory.

An upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=4a491b1ab11ca0556d2fda1ff1301e862a2d44c4

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Via RHSA-2018:3096 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:3096

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2018:2948 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:2948
